title: When `JsonRpc.EngineHost` is a hostname, then it listens only on IPv6, and on `::`
body:
**Description**

this is how i start nethermind 1.22.0, i.e. `EngineHost` is set to the hostname `serlap.lan`:

```
nethermind --JsonRpc.EnginePort=8551 --JsonRpc.EngineHost=serlap.lan --JsonRpc.Port=8545 --JsonRpc.Host=serlap.lan --JsonRpc.Enabled=true [...]
```

this is how it's listening after starting up:
```
# netstat -lnp | grep nether
tcp6       0      0 0.0.0.0:30303           :::*                    LISTEN      7975/nethermind     
tcp6       0      0 :::8551                 :::*                    LISTEN      7975/nethermind     
tcp6       0      0 :::8545                 :::*                    LISTEN      7975/nethermind     
udp6       0      0 0.0.0.0:30303           :::*                                7975/nethermind     
unix  2      [ ACC ]     STREAM     LISTENING     36170956 7975/nethermind      /tmp/dotnet-diagnostic-7975-6845026-socket
```

and this is what `serlap.lan` resolves to:
```
# nslookup serlap.lan
Server:         127.0.0.1
Address:        127.0.0.1#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:   serlap.lan
Address: 10.0.8.103
Name:   serlap.lan
Address: [ipv6 address]
Name:   serlap.lan
Address: [ipv6 address]
```

**Actual behavior**

it only listens on IPv6 and on the `::` (all) interface.

**Expected behavior**

it listens on all the ip addresses that the specified host resolves to, and not on `::`, unless so speficied.

if it is not already possible (how?) then probably there should be support to add multiple host ip addresses one way or another. maybe through allowing multiple `--JsonRpc.EngineHost` entries, or comma separated.

same applies to `--JsonRpc.Host`.

**Desktop:**
 - Operating System: Guix (a linux), with this channel: https://github.com/attila-lendvai/guix-crypto
 - Version: 1.22.0
 - Installation Method: https://github.com/attila-lendvai/guix-crypto
 - Consensus Client: Lighthouse

**Additional context**

ultimately i want it to only listen on the lan addresses, so i want to be able to specify multiple ip addresses (one of the IPv6 address that `serlap.lan` resolves to is a global address).

it's low priority, i can survive without this feature, because i need to set up a firewall anyway.
